lexUnit.name: scramble.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: move or climb hurriedly, possibly using one's hand

sentence.text: As soon as the final wheel nut was tightened , he started up and men scrambled aboard .
But as the boy scrambled about , he stood on a skylight and fell about 12ft into the room below .
Woolly monkeys and howlers , spider monkeys and capuchins , tamarins and marmosets scramble around one another reaching for the fruit .
The gunmen continued to fire at the house after he managed to scramble inside and slam the front door shut .
The females move down from the cliffs , across the shingle to the breakers , scrambling over one another in their anxiety to get to the water .
We walked on , jumping over trickles of water , squelching through soggy bits , scrambling over dry stands of heather , bouncing off spongy peat , clambering around rocky outcrops .
A wren or robin scrambled about in a clump of thorns and seemed to be scolding .
Within seconds , I 'd rolled over the parapet , scrambled along the lead gutter to the hatch , drawn the bolt and entered -- all without giving my head time to jam the works .
They then scrambled along ducting and into Court No 2 at Manchester Crown Court before escaping to the street through an unlocked fire door .
She scrambled along on leftover momentum , using her hands and knees more than her feet .
Forster scrambled along to the telegraph and rang the order .
As the show is brought up to performance night , 100 people can be scrambling around the stage .
He scrambled away on all fours , not stopping until he reached the dirty blank wall of the piggery twenty feet away .
Cardiff fired blindly into the roaring , shrieking mass as he began to scramble back up the stairs .
Willie fought back the urge to leave , to scramble back up the embankment and join his mates as if nothing had happened .
The survivors scrambled back to the sepoy lines pursued by a vengeful squadron of Sikh cavalry .
Jack and Wise were thrown into the water , but scrambled back onto the aircraft , which remained afloat .
She pulled away and scrambled back to her side of the seat , but not before he gave her a knowing little smile .

Before Isabel could retort in kind , Edmund scrambled nimbly back over the wall with the assistance of its thick covering of climbing roses , putting a long slash in his white linen shirt in the process .
She scrambled down the tree as fast as she could .
The four men looked up as he came scrambling down the steep bank .
The pictures , Britta realized , were the views seen by the Counsellors as they scrambled down the slope towards the wrecked craft .
Then fear overcame curiosity and he scrambled down from the tree with such haste that he skinned his knees and gouged a long deep gash along the inside of his forearm .
He scrambled down from his chair and looked hopefully at Nick , and when he said , ` Do you mean you want us to come and help milk the cow ? "
Somehow she scrambled down into the hollow and landed on her knees by Fand .
On impulse , Jack scrambled in , leaving the security guard still looking puzzled .
The steward scrambled off the bar stool and disappeared through the swing door .
Mortified , she scrambled off the bed , and dashed for the door .
While Pamella flung a few things in a suitcase and scrambled off to Bali tout de suite , Fleet Street fanned out to play cherchez la femme .
Passengers were still climbing off while the second load of passengers were scrambling on .
Then he and his three uninjured crew scrambled on to life-rafts -- and were themselves rescued by helicopter .
He scrambled frantically out , coughing and spluttering .
He scrambled out blindly on to the damp grass while Mr Chan rattled at the lock of the boot .
I unstrapped the seatbelt and scrambled out .
A sharp , heavy knock sent Nadia scrambling out into the cold half-light of the early morning .
He allowed a thin , ill-clad woman to scramble out behind it , and immediately she fell to her knees beside the body and began wailing once more .
She scrambled over the garden fence and joined them , shy , thrilled .
We scramble over the boulders to inspect the rapid below .
Watching her parents scramble round the slippery rocks , she savoured the thought .
Three wide arches support the slab front and back ; I could easily scramble through .

4 After mile reach signpost indicating Woodgate on right , and continue half left on well-trodden path signposted Sheepdip to continue along main valley ( path blocked by fallen trees at time of writing but these are quite easy to scramble under ) .
I blame the fact that a crow chose to hover below me as I scrambled up a tricky bit of path , made more perilous by loose shifting gravel .
I scrambled up the side-wall of the canyon and peeped over .
The five of them scrambled up the narrow carpeted stairway .
Rae imagined the fear in her sunless face as she scrambled up the rough bark .
Andy suddenly jerks into motion and scrambles up onto the rim of the chimney .
Robyn saw the tightness in his expression , the grim set of his jaw and began to scramble up from her half-lying position on the settee .
The rolling of the waves against the rocky coastline made landing difficult , but finally they scrambled ashore .
Although he clearly wants to walk off the boat , the ambulance crew scramble on board and clamp him onto a stretcher , so firmly that I wonder if they think he might punch them .
The fourth boy , however , slipped and fell to his knees and was only beginning to scramble upright again when the fender caught his chest with a thud that shook the vehicle .
My legs folded , both knees hit the ground , and I scrambled , in a rage , back on to the wheelbarrow .
Craig scrambled free and the driver sped off .
Eager to cash in on this sorry state of affairs , big telecoms firms are scrambling to offer all-in-one ` global " telephone services to multinationals .
In the province , as firms scramble to win public sector contracts , the average tenders being offered are lagging far behind the actual cost of construction .

Supporters of Campbell , the defence minister from Vancouver , and Charest , the youthful environment minister from Quebec , were scrambling to woo uncommitted delegates in a closer-than-expected race .
The World Jewish Congress ( WJC ) also said the French government withdrew its offer of a plane to fly the refugees to Israel , leaving organisers to scramble to find another aircraft .
It was all she could do to scramble behind trying to keep up with the long , impatient strides .
Observing his target through cold eyes , Mortimer strode ahead , pistol ready , marking the positions of the dark figures who could be made out scrambling about the building .
Others had scrambled across the field , dodging shellbursts , and had taken off only to forget where they were supposed to be going .
Anabelle scrambled across the footbridge to the other side of the canal .
They scrambled from the police car and headed down a narrow alleyway , their hands resting lightly on their sheathed batons .
She watched as they scrambled from the truck , running after Lais , wishing their footsteps did n't crunch so loudly on the gravel .
Peter desperately tried to scramble from the wreckage , fearing the car would burst into flames .
He got up , scrambled into his clothes , and chucked it in his wardrobe .
Trying to ignore the buzzing in her head , which was like a badly-tuned radio , she scrambled into her clothes .

He sat up , naked and at ease , handing the swiftly discarded T-shirt to her from the floor , watching while she scrambled self-consciously into her clothes with an expression that Robyn did n't dare to read .
Clarissa closed hers quickly and scrambled into some clothes .
Nicola scrambled backwards on heels and hands .
He scrambled energetically onto a chair , and set himself to be like them .
They scrambled onto the upturned hull and drifted for more than 20 minutes before coming to rest on a bank two miles away .
Either offside or obstruction , or both , could have been awarded against Wasps as they scrambled after the ball as the final line-out , which they lost , broke up .
Then he sent staff and customers scrambling for cover by hurling a smoke bomb into the chain 's restaurant in Kensington , London .
Labourers began to scramble for the available employment ; unemployment increased ; while labourers still continued to anticipate marriage .
Blows were exchanged between members of the audience somewhere at the front and the whole scene developed into a riot , with others not wishing to get involved in a fight scrambling for the exit .
They went swiftly into operation , scrambling for seats on planes and pillows in resorts , while shops reordered from importers as their stocks of ski equipment sold out .
Rachel scrambled desperately for the other side of the bed .
THOUSANDS of Gaelic football fans in Co Londonderry today scrambled for tickets to next weekend 's All-Ireland Final at Croke Park in Dublin .
Somebody called , ` Tea 's ready , " and the bathers scrambled out of the water and began drying themselves .
For two perfect Sundays they scrambled side-by-side over the lichen-dappled rocks of the valley wall , the aquamarine sky above reflected in the ribbon of sea below them .
There was a council of war , a pause for prayer ( ` Quiet time , Quakers ! " called someone ) and they scrambled past the wire once more .
He eventually scrambled through the door and onto the top of the sinking tanker .
When they were still two miles away his headlights caught a half-naked figure trying to scramble through a hedge .
Bernice scrambled madly through the twisted wreckage as Anushkia Smyslov lost herself in the chaos , shouting orders .
I scrambled to my feet a little sheepishly as one of the Officers had turned round and was observing me as I approached .
Fernando drew away from her and Ruth scrambled to her feet , smoothing the creases from her dress .
In the hushed silence that followed he scrambled to his feet , his face and neck flushing scarlet .
One of the tyres burst but the Travolta family and the others on board scrambled to safety .
She thrust the exercise book into a coat pocket and scrambled to the window by which she had entered .
